thread.title: Child killer described as 'gentle giant' by family
thread.title_full: Child killer described as 'gentle giant' by family

author: Deena Coster
title: Child killer described as 'gentle giant' by family

persons.name: robert charles/fairfax nz  philip murray kinraid

text:
Dad jailed for suffocating his toddler daughter Child killer described as 'gentle giant' by family DEENA COSTER Last updated 12:56, February 22 2017 Andy Jackson/Fairfax NZ 
On Wednesday, Philip Murray Kinraid was sent to prison for four years and three months for causing the death of his two-year-old daughter. 
The last minutes of Esme Kinraid's life must have been terrifying. 
Struggling for breath, as her cries were muffled under the weight of her father. 
Philip Murray Kinraid's actions snuffed out the life of his two-year-old girl in just a matter of minutes. Robert Charles/Fairfax NZ 
Philip Murray Kinraid during his first appearance in the Hawera District Court after Esme's death. 
In doing so, Esme became part of the country's bleakest statistic - its child death toll. 
On average, nine children are killed every year in New Zealand, usually by someone who is meant to provide them with love and care. 
READ MORE: * March for Moko brings together all sides of the domestic violence debate 
On Wednesday, Philip Kinraid was jailed for four years and three months after he caused Esme's death on June 26, 2015. The 29-year-old previously pleaded guilty to manslaughter. 
After trying to settle Esme to sleep for the night, he restrained her in bed, pushing her face into a pillow for up to ten minutes. 
He left the room, thinking she was still alive, but when he checked back hours later, she was not breathing or moving. Attempts to revive her failed. Deena Coster 
The Hawera house the Kinraid family lived in at the time of Esme's death. 
Prior to his arrest, Philip Kinraid appeared to have a lot going right for him. Ad Feedback 
In 2010, he graduated from the University of Otago with a Bachelor of Science with Honours degree, majoring in chemistry. 
His career path eventually landed him in Hawera, South Taranaki where he lived with his young family - his partner and two children. 
As the breadwinner for the family, he worked as a chemical engineer for Fonterra, a job which can attract a salary of up to $120,000 a year. 
There were no outward signs of what was to come, people have said. They were just a normal family, living on a quiet street in a small town. 
So news of Esme's sudden death was a massive blow for those who knew the family. 
A friend of the Kinraids, who asked not to be named, said it had shattered the close knit Hawera community. 
"It all came as a real, big shock," she said. 
"She was just a really lively two-year-old, who absolutely loved her family to bits." 
She said the Kinraid family appeared to be stable and there were no outwards signs of any problems. 
It had been especially difficult to explain Esme's death to her own children, who used to play with the little girl from time to time. 
"She (Esme) was just starting to come out of her shell and socialise with other children," she said. 
When she first heard about what happened, she thought a stranger had to have been responsible for Esme's death - someone must have broken into the home and hurt the child. 
"In no way did I think it was her own father," she said. 
"He seemed like a solid bloke, with a solid job. He was a family man." 
She said she last had contact with Esme's mother and older brother about a year ago. They were coping as best they could in an attempt to re-build their lives, she said.
